Ranked: choice voting allows voters to rank candidates from best to worst on their ballot instead of voting for just one person.
The numbers aren: t in on whether ranked-choice voting actually has a concrete impact on turnout or engagement in the long term.
Kelley Dragoo: the Green Party candidate for Missouri’s lieutenant governor seat, claims that ranked-choice voting saves money and mitigates the problem of having to pick a "lesser of two evils," among other benefits.
Fairvote cites a 2016 study by professor: St. Louis, which found that ranked-choice voting was associated with a roughly 9 percentage point increase in voter turnout in municipal elections.
